guide.title: Gentoo Linux Preliminary CVSUP Guide
guide.abstract: This guide provides a rough sketch of how to get cvsup working as a Gentoo alternative to rsync.

body.p: Unsurprisingly, you need to have the cvsup package installed.
The cvsup ebuild provides both the cvsup client and the cvsupd server.

chapter.title: Setting up the main Gentoo CVSUP server

body.p: The main Gentoo cvsup server needs to make the Gentoo cvs repository available to mirrors, and deny access to anybody else. At the moment we'll only consider the portage tree, and hold off on gentoo-src until later.
body.pre: # mkdir -p /etc/cvsup/sup/portage # echo "cvs list=list.cvs prefix=/path/to/cvs/repository" > /etc/cvsup/sup/portage/releases # echo "upgrade gentoo-x86" > /etc/cvsup/sup/portage/list.cvs # cat << EOF > /etc/cvsup/cvsupd.access # allow localhost (and any allowed gentoo mirrors) +127.0.0.1/32 # deny all else -0.0.0.0/0 EOF # /etc/init.d/cvsupd start
body.p: The cvsupd server looks for repositories that it will serve under /etc/cvsup/sup, and at the moment we are only serving one we've labelled portage. The next two lines actually set up what "portage" is serving, with the "upgrade gentoo-x86" line telling cvsupd to serve the gentoo-x86 cvs module. That's all we need to do to get the server working!
Of course, we don't want everybody connecting to cvs.gentoo.org, since we don't have the bandwidth for that. The cvsupd.access file is used to restrict access to localhost and allowed gentoo mirrors.

body.p: and /var/cvsup/repository/gentoo-x86 will then store the portage repository.
body.note: The repository stored in /var/cvsup/repository/gentoo-x86 is an actual copy of the cvs repository, complete with RCS files, and not just a cvs checkout.

body.p: Essentially we do the same here as on the main Gentoo cvsupd server, only without the access restrictions.
body.pre: # mkdir -p /etc/cvsup/sup/portage # echo "cvs list=list.cvs prefix=/var/cvsup/repository" > \ > /etc/cvsup/sup/portage/releases # echo "upgrade gentoo-x86" > /etc/cvsup/sup/portage/list.cvs # /etc/init.d/cvsupd start
body.p: Your mirror should be good to go!

The user should find a /usr/gentoo-x86 directory now exists. (Also, some cvsup bookkeeping stuff has been generated in /var/cvsup.) To use this new directory as /usr/portage you just need to move the old directory aside and make a symlink:
body.pre: # cd /usr # mv portage portage.old # ln -s gentoo-x86 portage # mv portage.old/distfiles/* portage/distfiles # mv portage.old/packages/* portage/packages
body.p: (The last two lines just relocate all of the distfiles and packages that you've aquired to their new home.)
